Of all the environmental problems our planet is facing today, overpopulation is the one that sometimes slips from the radar. Overpopulation places a great demand on resources and land, which may be the reason for widespread environmental issues in addition to impacting global economies and standards of living.
Poverty is to be believed as the major cause of overpopulation. High mortality rate and lack of educational resources, leads to high birth rates, resulting in a large population.
If overpopulation grows, this effect is said to be so widespread that the United Nations has predicted that the 48 poorest countries of the world contribute to the largest population growth. They estimate that the combined population of these countries is expected to be 1.7 billion in 2050 from 850 million in 2010.

The effects of the overpopulation are quite severe. One of these is the lack of natural resources. Earth has the capacity to only produce a limited amount of food and water, falling short of current needs of the people which are increasing day by day.

Rapid population growth makes the choice between high consumption and investment needed to bring more consumption in the future more scarce. Economic development depends on investment. Therefore, rapid population growth repels the investment needed for higher future consumption.

With a rapidly growing population, the adjustment becomes difficult to manage with economic and social change. Urbanization in UDC creates problems like housing, electricity, water, transport etc. In addition, the growing population is at risk of permanent environmental damage through urbanization in some rural areas.

The rapidly growing population transforms the economy into mass unemployment and low employment. As the population increases, the ratio of workers to the total population increases. The result is that with an increase in the labour force, unemployment and low employment increases. Rapid increment of the population reduces savings and investment.

Domestic consumption of exportable goods also increases with rapid population growth. As a result, there is a decline in the exportable surplus. On the other hand just to meet the demand of the rapidly growing population, more food and other consumer goods are needed so that demand can be fulfilled.

I also think it's odd not to include GMOs, as pretty much most food as been genetically modified by humans over years via selective breeding. The meat of many fruits has gotten fuller while seeds have shrunk due to humans deliberately breeding them like that over time, modifying the population's genes. Excellent information!  Before hybrid seeds became available in the early 1930's, farmers grew a wide verity of seed crops that were hardy and thrived on their land.  There were hundreds of varieties of corn and beans.  After plants were bred for uniformity to allow for mechanical harvesting, many plant varieties were lost forever.  Had it not been for farm and gardening families who kept growing the heirloom seed and later the Seed Savers Exchange,  our farm crops family tree today would look like a telephone pole.    To better see understand the urgent need for banking plant genetics.  By growing a national crop that has the same genetics, you have the making of the Great Irish Potato Famine of 1845.  ~ Thank you for making people more aware of the value of preserving our food plants genetic treasures for the Future.

I have never used marijuana (or any other illegal substance for that matter), nor do I advocate for its use beyond explicit medical necessity.
That being said, despite how humans regard and/or treat it, marijuana exists on this planet as part of a naturally-occurring evolution of the ecosystem. It exists today- just all other plants and animals do- as proof of "survival of the fittest". When/if that disaster finally comes, and we need to literally re-seed the planet, why would you not include samples of every single plant available!? Again, regardless of how humans deal with it, marijuana is part of Earth-born wildlife and serves its purpose along with every other plant.

(NOTE: I'm only bringing this up because the video brought up marijuana, not because I advocate one way-or-the-other on its use!)

This question came about from me playing with 2d gravity physics in programming. Without applying some code to reduce the y axis velocity of the ball that is bouncing to zero when it gets to very small bounces, the ball seems to want to bounce forever. Since the screen can only show me 1 pixel bounces, the ball ends up bouncing 1 pixel up and down forever. In reality there is a lot more going on and it would be awesome to try and code some of that into my 2d ball physics program.

Derek, can you tell me if when you drop a bouncing ball from any height onto a flat surface why it does not bounce forever with smaller and smaller distances upwards each bounce. I think this may be thermodynamic effects preventing the ball from bouncing ever smaller and smaller distances upwards. It may also be related to the shockwave distributing energy inside the ball as it bounces. Maybe it even has some quantum effects stopping this as well. Well, i lost so much respect for this vault when i saw how it was organized. It's basically just a lot of people of high status from different countries that have sent boxes of seeds that might not even be matching the kind it says on the box, and they can't even check to see if they are the correct seeds. Also, the contract seems like something that would not really solve the problem:
"Oh yeah, you can deposit this box of seeds to us that we will most likely not open for about a hundred years when we really need them, but you have to sign this contract to prove that you give us the right seeds since we are not allowed to check what the boxes contain."

They don't allow drug related plants, really? Why? Drugs have many more uses than illicitly , to get high.

For example, the one in particular that absolutely should be in there is opium. Opium changed the world of medicine. Before we figured out how to extract out the morphine, surgery was basically non existent. Opium is the only practical source of opioid based chemicals in nature, and it is absolutely essential for any basic health care system.

So, my point is that these "illicit" plants should be allowed their rightful place in here. They have their uses, good uses. And perhaps they even have as of yet unknown uses that could be beneficial.

I would love to meet the salesman who convinced a bunch of government officials to invest in a billion dollar vault, to act as an insurance for an event that probably won't happen and even if it should: someone who needs access to it would have to overcome a series of almost impossible tasks: it's built at such a remote location that should we be nuked out or blasted by an asteroid, reaching it would require a long and dangerous journey. and if you get there you probably can't get in due to the high level of automated security (the people working there might not survive an extinction level event). let's say you get to the seeds you not only have to transfer them back to a place that can be safely planted, but (since the system is based purely on people's honesty) you have to hope that the label actually corresponds with the contents (you might end up with weed instead of corn in three months time). further more, the labeling system presents a problem: after an extinction level event or nuking, chances that the internet would be active and accessible to figure out what's in which box is pretty thin...

~ The goal of the seed vault is not solely for food crops.

~ We have 3 entities with different missions. One is focused on preserving genetic materials of seeds. The other is focused on preserving genetic materials for food security. The third is focused on both preserving genetic materials of seeds and genetic materials for food security.

(~ = my comment; everything else is copy/pasted from source material)

Wikipedia states: "The seed vault is an attempt to insure against the loss of seeds in other gene-banks during large-scale regional or global crises." (Reference article: NordGen itself)

Wikipedia states that its mission is: "The Svalbard Global Seed Vault's mission is to provide a safety net against accidental loss of diversity in traditional genebanks." (Reference article: The Economist (3rd party viewpoint))

From the Royal Norwegian Ministry of Agriculture and Food's, which (I think) is the main member of Svalbard Global Seed Vault: "The Seed Vault is a gene bank, where scientists and others can apply directly to access seeds. There are many national, regional and international seed collections and gene banks around the world whose primary function is to ensure genetic diversity in the agriculture sector. The Svalbard Seed Vault is a safety stock for these local deposits, which can be used to recreate valuable plant varieties whose seed collections in a local gene bank are lost." (Official website)

~ This one states that it's a gene-bank. Biorepositories which preserves the genetic materials of seeds do not (and I argue should not) distinguish between which ones are "good" and which ones are "bad." To make such distinctions or similar would be a subjective process of determining which seeds to preserve.

The Global Seed Diversity Trust is the second member with the mission statement: "Our mission is to ensure the conservation and availability of crop diversity for food security worldwide." (Official website)

~ This one specifies crops for food security.

Nordic Genetic Resource Center (NordGen) is the last member and its mission statement is two-fold: (1) "to be the gene bank of plants and a knowledge center for the dissemination of information on sustainable conservation and utilization of plant" and (2) "to secure sustainable solutions in relation to food security and to a bio-based economy, by ensuring the conservation and promote the use of genetic resources in agriculture" (Official website)

~ This one states both food and agriculture.

________

Definitions that apply to Svalbard Global Seed Vault:

Agriculture: Cultivation of plants for (1) food, (2) fiber, (3) biofuel, (4) medicinal and (5) other products used to sustain and enhance human life. (International Labor Organization)
Agriculture: The science, art, or practice of cultivating the soil, producing crops, and in varying degrees the preparation and marketing of the resulting products. (M-W)
Agriculture: The science or practice of farming, including cultivation of the soil for the growing of crops.(Oxford)

Crop: Any cultivated plant that is harvested for (1) food, (2) clothing, (3) livestock fodder, (4) biofuel, (5) medicine, (6) or other uses. (Wikipedia)
Crop: A plant or plant product that can be grown and harvested extensively for profit or subsistence (M-W)
Crop: A cultivated plant that is grown on a large scale commercially. (Oxford)

A problem with this vault is that, just recently we found that there are several species of fungus that permeate the medium between the plant cells(helping they grow providing metabolites and evolving with them, meaning that they acquire metabolic ways), and they are specific to a variety of the plant, meaning that for this type of plant this fungus may be deadly to other kinds of plants. And the most astounding fact is that they can be transferred through seeds. The same thing can be expected from viruses, they can implant in the genome and remain dormant for years, and again, can be transferred through seeds.
So in a sense, the Svalbard seed deposit may be carrying viruses and fungus as well and not just plants for our survival. Not that those living beings would be wiped out in the worst case scenario but, since they mutate much faster than plants, our own seeds could be carrying their doom inside of them.
